title-group.article-title: Preliminary study on mechanism of cavitation in lubricant of textured sliding bearing

article-meta.aff: The State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Transmission, Chongqing University, Chongqing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: FM Meng, The State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Transmission, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, People’s Republic of China. Email: fmmeng@cqu.edu.cn

abstract.p: The mechanism of the cavitation in a lubricant of a textured sliding bearing is studied based on multiphase flow theories and tribological equations. First, a physical model for a bearing with a series of semi-spherical dimples is modeled through commercial software ANSYS. Then, influences of dimple position and sizes on the vapor volume fraction, and cavitated area of the bearing are studied with computational fluid dynamic method. Numerical results show that the obvious fluctuation of the vapor volume rate and changes in the starting and end angles of the cavitation region due to varied dimple position can occur, when the dimples are located in the cavitated region. Moreover, with increasing cavitation starting angle, the changing trend of the cavitated area is the same as that of the load-carrying capacity, but opposite to the variation trends of the friction force and further friction coefficient.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of micro-machining, intensive attentions have been paid to surface texturing due to its ability to improve performances for tribological pairs. In 2003, a pin-on-disc experiment by Wakuda et al.1 revealed that a hydrodynamic lubrication effect can be established between the two parallel textured surface due to the dimple’s action as a lubricant reservoir. In 2004, Uehara et al.2 found that the friction of the textured silicon nitride ceramic ring can decrease due to the dimple effect. In 2005, the numerical simulation by Sahlin3 showed that the load-carrying capacity of oil film for dimpled surfaces increases with increasing Reynolds number of lubricant. In 2008, Pascovici et al.4 pointed out that the tribological performances of flat-to-flat dimpled surfaces are closely related to the number, size, and density of dimples. In 2009, Meng et al.5 analyzed influences of the orientation of textured rough surface on tribological performances of the surface. Since the cavitation of lubricant often occurs for operating tribological pairs, the cavitation effect on a textured surface has been studied by a few researchers. In 2006, Olver et al.6 investigated the lubricant’s inlet suction effect on cavitation. In 2007, Qiu and Khonsari7 pointed out that the Reynolds equation largely underestimates cavitation effect for lubricated pairs with big Reynolds number, small film thickness, or surface roughness. In order to account for the inertia effect of lubricant under the above three conditions, the general Navier–Stokes equation (N–S equation) rather than the Reynolds equation should be adopted for simulating textured surfaces. In 2010, computational fluid dynamic (CFD) method was used for solving N–S equation by Han et al.8 to study the effects of Reynolds number of lubricant on the film pressure, load-carrying capacity, friction force and friction coefficient of textured surfaces. In 2011, this method was also employed by Shi and Ni9 to study cavitation mechanism of parallel surfaces with grooved textures.

Besides the above studies of parallel (or approximate parallel) textured surface, a few researches about textured bearings have also been studied. In 2005, Tala-Ighil et al.10 compared performances of globally and locally dimpled bearing surfaces, and found that the latter can better improve the bearing performances. About 2 years later, they further suggested that the bearing performances can be improved through appropriate texture geometry sizes and their distributions.11 In 2008, CFD computation by Cupillard et al.12 showed that surface texturing can increase the load-carrying capacity of a plain bearing, and reduce its friction coefficient. In 2009, Cupillard et al.13 further pointed out that the surface texturing has a strong and positive influence on the load-carrying capacity when the thermal effect of lubricant is considered. Sinanoglu et al.14 carried out an experiment of a dimpled shaft, which showed that appropriately dimpled journal shaft can improve the bearing’s performances. In 2010, Papadopoulo et al.15 presented a method for optimizing the geometry size of three-dimensional (3D) micro-thrust bearings in a wide range of convergence ratios. In 2011, Qiu and Khonsari16 studied the cavitation pressure effect on tribological performance of mechanical seal-like thrust bearings with dimples by solving the Reynolds equation with a mass conservative algorithm.

Despite the above work, the cavitation mechanism of a dimpled bearing has not been studied with CFD method to date. This is worthy being explored, since cavitation can directly change bearing performances according to lubrication practices and since CFD method can accurately predict performances of textured surfaces, as stated previously. However, discussing every kind of effects of the influencing factors on the cavitation mechanism is difficult. In this article, only a few influencing factors, i.e. dimple distribution, dimple depth and its width, are to be analyzed, which play important roles in cavitation analyses but not being considered in previous bearing researches. The article is organized as follows. A simulation model for a textured sliding bearing is presented first. Then, associated multiphase flow theories and tribological equations are used to analyze the cavitation mechanism under the condition of the above three factors with CFD method through commercial software ANSYS 11.0. Further, the cavitation mechanism for the dimpled bearing will be revealed for the varied position and geometry sizes of the dimple.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: In this study, the cavitation model of Rayleigh–Plesset equation is used for analyzing the influence of the cavitation in lubricant on tribological performances of a sliding bearing. This model is used also by Cupillard et al.12 for studying tribological performances of a sliding bearing. The cavitation is involved in the vaporization of lubricant, which is a dynamic process of the exchanged lubricant and gas. The mass rate of vapored lubricant can be approximately expressed as (1)m·v=N·ρv·4πRb·R·=N·ρv·4πRb2 ·23|pv-p|ρlsgn(pv-p) where N is the number of bubble per unit volume, ρv the density of the vapored lubricant, and gas nuclear radius Rb is taken to be 1 µm in this study. The radius of the cavitation bubble is denoted by R, whose variation of the radius per unit time is R.. The pressure inside the bubble is denoted by pv. p is the pressure surrounding the bubble and ρl the liquid lubricant density. The above ρl can be determined according to the following equation (2)∂∂xj(ρlujαl)=m·l where uj are the velocity vectors (j = 1, 2, 3), representing lubricant velocities in x-, y-, and z-directions, which are determined by the following mass and momentum equations. The volume fraction of liquid lubricant αl in equation (2) can be obtained (3)αl+αv=1 where αv is the relative amount of the volume fraction of vapored lubricant.
In order to achieve the dynamic balance of exchanged mass, the following exchanged mass rate should be satisfied (4)m·l=-m·v where m·l is the exchanged liquid lubricant in the cavitation process.

Based on an assumption that there exists a common velocity for the liquid and vapored lubricants, the mass equation for the two phases is expressed as (5)∂∂xj(ρuj)=0 where the mixed density ρ=ρlαl+ρvαv.
The momentum equation for the two phases (6)∂(ρujui)∂xj=-∂τij∂xj-∂p∂xi where p is the film pressure and τij the strain tensors, whose expressions are omitted here.
To solve the above equations, the finite volume method is employed with the CFX modules of commercial software ANSYS 11.0. It should be pointed out that the above equations are solved simultaneously.

Once the film pressure is determined, with a post-processing method, the load-carrying capacity of oil film can be obtained according to the integral of the pressure along the circumferential direction of the bearing, given below (7)Fx=-∫02πprcosθdθ (8)Fy=-∫02πprsinθdθ

sec.title: Simulation models
sec.p: A bearing model with a series of semi-spherical dimples is shown in Figure 1(a). For this type of dimple, cavitation occurs easily due to the divergence and convergence edges of the bearing, where the lubricant flows from the leading edge of the dimple toward its trailing edge. In Figure 1(a), the eccentricity distance between geometry centers for the bearing and shaft (o and oi, respectively) is denoted by the symbol e, and the maximum and minimum films are hmax=c+e and hmin=c-e, respectively. The symbol c is the bearing clearance, R the inner radius of bearing, r the radius of shaft, and θ the counterclockwise circumferential angle from the maximum film thickness. The starting and end angles for the dimpled region with the reference angular position taken at the maximum film thickness are denoted by θa and θb, respectively. The opening angle of dimpled region Δθ=θb-θa. The starting and end angles for cavitated area are denoted by θi and θe, respectively. Figure 1(b) illustrates a dimple located on the inner surface of the bearing, where the width and depth of the dimple are w and d, respectively.

In the simulation, the bearing is meshed using a hexahedron element with eight nodes, and the whole number of the element is 600 × 10 in the θ- and r-directions. This type of the element is also used to mesh the dimples. For every dimple, its number of element is 20 × 12 in the bearing’s width and its depth directions, as shown in Figure 2. The outer surface of the bearing is constrained against the θ- and r-directions. The lubricant velocity on the inner surface of the bearing is set to be zero, while the same rotational speed as that of the shaft is used for the velocity of lubricant on the shaft. In addition, no slip occurs on all walls, and residual convergences for the pressure and velocity of lubricant in equations (5) and (6) are both set to be 1.0 × 10−5. The present numerical results show that when the above set of mesh grid system is used for simulation, the resulting computation error is less than 5%, which is usually acceptable for an engineering application. Therefore, such number of mesh grid and residual convergences are used in the computations of the following cases analyzed, if no other explanations. Figure 2.
Mesh of an illustrated dimple.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p:
Before the cavitation effect is analyzed, it is necessary to test the validity of the numerical implementation. A comparison in the film pressure between results from the present study and Cupillard et al.12 is given in Figure 3, where all the input parameters for the present simulation are the same as those used in Cupillard et al.12 It can be observed from Figure 3 that a good agreement between the two kinds of pressures can be observed clearly, especially in the cavitation region. Therefore, all subsequent calculations are conducted based on the present bearing model. Figure 3.
Comparison between simulated pressures and data in Cupillard et al.12 for a smooth sliding bearing.

sec.title: Performances for smooth and dimpled bearings
sec.p: In the simulation, the cavitation effects are analyzed for the bearing with semi-spherical dimples located at six different positions (cases 1–6) of the inner surface of the bearing. The starting angle of the dimpled region for these cases is 52°, 122°, 142°, 182°, 212°, and 262°, respectively. These positions belong to the rising, maximum, and falling parts of pressure, respectively. In the following computation, the same ten dimples with the opening angle Δθ = 48° are evenly distributed on the inner surface of the bearing along the circumferential coordinate, as denoted by D1–D10 shown in Figure 1(a).

For every dimple with the texture extent Δθ = 48°, its width w is taken to be 3 and 4 mm, and its depth d is taken to be 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1 mm, respectively. For convenience of analysis, the dimensionless cavitated area SC=(θe-θi)/360∘ is introduced, where θe and θi are, respectively, the starting and end angles of cavitated region. In the simulation, geometric sizes and working parameters for the bearing analysis are presented in Table 1, which are drawn from Cupillard et al.12 Table 1.
Parameters for simulating the sliding bearing.
Shaft radius 50 mm
Bearing clearance 0.145 mm
Eccentricity ratio 0.61
Rotational speed 48.1 rad/s
Lubricant density 840 kg/m3
Lubricant viscosity 0.0127 Pas
Density of vapor in lubricant 1.2 kg/m3
Viscosity vapor in lubricant 0.00002 Pas
Saturation vapor pressure 20 kPa

Figure 4(a) gives the film pressures for a smooth bearing with and without the consideration of cavitation effects. It can be seen from this figure that the pressure peak increases by about 20.3% if the cavitation effect is considered. Figure 4(b) gives the vapor volume fraction with the cavitation effect consideration, where the dimensionless cavitation area Sc = 0.326, and the cavitation starting and end angles are respectively 201.5° and 319.1°. For the mixed state of lubricant and gas, 80% of the fraction shows that the vapor is dominant, which is in agreement with conclusions drawn by Dowson and Taylor.17 Figure 4.
Pressure and vapor volume fraction against circumferential position for smooth bearing: (a) pressure with and without cavitations; (b) vapor volume fraction.

Table 2 presents relative percentage values between the load-carrying capacities, friction forces, and friction coefficients in cases 1–6 for the dimpled bearing and smooth bearing. It can be seen that not all dimple distributions can improve the load-carrying capacity and friction coefficient, although the friction force decreases due to the dimple effect, compared with their corresponding values in the smooth case. Generally, cases 2 and 4 are the better positions, where the load-carrying capacity is bigger than that at other positions, while the friction coefficient is smaller than that at other positions. sec.title: Vapor volume fraction at varied position
sec.p:
In this section, the dimple width w and its depth d are taken to be, respectively, 4 and 1 mm. Figure 5 gives the vapor volume fraction against the circumferential position. The bigger fraction, the severer the cavitation of lubricant. As shown in Figure 5(a) to (c), the vapor fraction in the dimpled region is zero when the dimples are located at the rising part of pressure, whose amplitude and distribution are both similar to their corresponding values in the smooth case, stated previously. This is due to the phenomenon that the pressure in this case does not change, compared with that in smooth case shown in Figure 4(a). For the last three sub-figures shown in Figure 5(d) to (f) where the dimples are located at the maximum or falling part of pressure, i.e. the cavitation region, the vapor volume fractions in the dimpled regions are larger than zero and fluctuate. This is caused by discontinuous pressure in this region, as shown in Figure 6(b) to (d). Figure 5.
Vapor volume fractions at different dimple positions (w = 4 mm, d = 1 mm).
Figure 6.
Pressure profiles in different cases (w = 4 mm, d = 1 mm).

Figure 7 further gives the vapor volume fraction in case 2 against the circumferential position, where the dimple width varies from 3 to 4 mm, and the dimple depth d ranges between 0.25 and 1 mm. It can be observed from this figure that the cavitation still does not occur at the dimpled region. However, increasing dimple depth brings out the variation in the amplitude of the vapor volume fraction of the cavitated region. For the dimple width w = 3 mm, the fraction is the biggest at d = 0.5 mm, about 90%. For the dimple width w = 4 mm, the biggest fraction occurs at d = 1 mm. The difference shows that the vapor volume fraction is close to the depth of dimple located in the convergent region. The same conclusion holds for cases 1 and 3. Figure 7.
Vapor volume fraction for case 2 at varied dimple depth.
Left column: w = 3 mm; right column: w = 4 mm.

Figure 8 gives the vapor volume fraction in case 4 as a function of the circumferential position, where the dimple depth varies from 0.25 to 1 mm. For the left column of the figure, the dimple width is 3 mm, while it is 4 mm for the right column. The varied dimple depth leads to the fluctuation of the fraction. The fraction variation against the dimple depth is concentrated in Figure 9, where the variation of the fraction with increased dimple depth can be found. However, for the same dimple depth, the fraction at w = 4 mm is bigger than that at w = 3 mm by comparing Figure 9(a) with (b). This implies that the varied dimple width can lead to a difference in the cavitation mechanism for the same dimple position. Figure 8.
Vapor volume fraction for case 4 at varied dimple depth.
Left column: w = 3 mm; right column: w = 4 mm.
Figure 9.
Variations of maximum vapor volume fraction for case 4 with varied dimple size.

In addition, the difference in the vapor volume fraction between cases 2 and 4 needs to be explored further. For case 2, the region of the dimples is between 122° and 170°, while the region for case 4 is between 182° and 230°. The former fraction is continuous, while the latter fraction is discontinuous. This difference can be explained by Figure 10 showing the flow fields in cases 2 and 4. In Figure 10, the dimple width w = 4 mm and its depth d = 1 mm. Figure 10.
Comparisons between results for cases 2 and 4 (w = 4 mm, d = 1 mm).

Figure 10(a) shows that no cavitation occurs in case 2 due to the phenomenon that the film pressure shown in Figure 10(b) is above the saturation vapor pressure (20 kPa). Figure 10(c) shows no obvious fluctuation of the lubricant velocity in case 2. However, severe cavitation appears in case 4, as shown in Figure 10(e), which results in the variation of the vapor volume fraction from zero to unity, as shown in Figure 10(d). Moreover, the pressures at the leading and trailing edges are both negative, being less than the saturation pressure. This negative pressure is caused by strong turbulence flow occurring at the leading and trailing edges, as shown in Figure 10(f). This turbulence flow results in the fluctuation of the vapor volume fraction, as shown in Figure 8.

sec.title: Cavitation position and cavitated area
sec.p:
In this section, the cavitation position and cavitated area will be discussed, since they play important roles in changing bearing’s performances. For the smooth bearing, the starting and end angles of the cavitated region are respectively 201.5° and 319.1°, and its percent cavitated area is 0.326, as shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. For the dimpled bearing, the above angles in cases 1–6 (denoted by C1–C6, respectively) are given in Figure 11, where the dotted lines are plotted for the smooth bearing. As shown in this figure, the two parameters both change due to the varied dimple position, compared with their corresponding values of the smooth bearing. Among all cases, the cavitated areas in cases 2 and 4 are smaller than their corresponding values in the smooth case, which explains why the two positions can improve the comprehensive performances of the bearing, as presented in Table 2. Similar conclusion can be drawn for other widths or depths of the dimple. Figure 11.
Cavitation position and cavitated area for different cases.

Figure 12 further examines the cavitation starting angle against the dimple depth in cases 2 and 4. An increasing starting angle means the delay of cavitation occurrence position. For case 2, the starting angle shows an upward trend when the dimple depth increases, then followed by a downward trend. For case 4, however, a linear increase in the starting angle can be found when the dimple depth increases. This implies that a there exists a difference in the cavitation mechanism for better dimple positions. Figure 12.
Cavitation starting angles for cases 2 and 4 against dimple depth.

Figure 13 gives the relationship between the cavitated area SC and relative variation of the load-carrying capacity Fr, defined as Fr=(F-Fs)/Fs. The symbols F and Fs represent distinctly the load-carrying capacities of dimpled and smooth bearings. As shown in Figure 13, with increasing cavitation starting angle, the variation trend of SC is opposite to that of Fr. An increases in SC leads to decreasing Fr. The cavitation of lubricant can bring out a decrease in the lubricant density, so the load-carrying capacity of lubricant perhaps drops off. Figure 13.
Relationship between dimensionless cavitated area and relative load-carrying capacity.

Further, the relationship is shown in Figure 14 between the cavitated area SC and relative variation of friction force Ffr at the varied dimple depth and its width. In this figure, Ffr=(Ff-Ffs)/Ffs. Here, Ff and Ffs are, respectively, the friction forces of oil film for the dimpled and smooth bearings. With increasing SC, Fr increases. Since the cavitation of lubricant perhaps lowers the load-carrying capacity, as stated previously, it is understandable that the friction force increases with increased cavitated area. Among all cases, the value of Ffr in case 4 is the smallest when the dimple depth or its width varies and other parameters are fixed, compared with that in other cases. The cavitated area in case 4, however, is not always the smallest, for example one shown in sub-figures excluding Figure 14(a) and (e). This shows that cavitation is only one of causes that bring out a falling friction force Figure 14.
Relationship between dimensionless cavitated area and relative friction force.

Figure 15 gives the relationship between the cavitated area SC and relative variation of the friction coefficient fr, defined as fr=(f-fs)/fs. Here, the symbols f and fs are the frictional coefficients of dimpled and smooth bearings, respectively. As shown in Figure 15, with increasing cavitation starting angle, the variation trend of fs is the same as that of SC. When SC increases, Fr becomes bigger. As stated previously, the cavitation of lubricant can result in a decrease in the load-carrying capacity and an increase in the friction force, and therefore the friction coefficient drops off. At the same dimple depth or its width, the value of fr in case 2 rather than in case 4 is the smallest of all the cases, but its cavitation area is not always so (cf. in Figure 15(a) and (e)). Figure 15.
Relationship between dimensionless cavitated area and relative friction coefficient.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The textured sliding bearing models with a series of the semi-spherical dimples are modeled based on multiphase flow theories and tribology equations. Then, the cavitation mechanisms at different positions and sizes of the dimple are studied with CFD method through CFX module of commercial software ANSYS11.0. The main conclusions are as follows:
When the dimples are located in the cavitated region of a sliding bearing, the significant fluctuation of the vapor volume fraction occurs. When the dimples are distributed in no-cavitated region in the bearing, the fluctuation of the fraction can be almost neglected.
A variation in the dimple position can change the starting and end angles of the cavitation region. An increase in the dimple depth can delay the starting position of cavitation region, if the dimples are located appropriately on the inner surface of the bearing.
With increasing cavitation starting angle, the changing trend of the cavitated area is the same as that of the load-carrying capacity, but opposite to the variation trends of the friction force and further friction coefficient.
The cavitation mechanism of bearing only with representive semi-spherical dimples is studied. Further investigation on the mechanism needs to be carried out at other conditions. However, it is convinced that this study can give a helpful reference to improving tribological performances of bearings with surface texturing.
